questions.question_text: A company is developing a new secure technology and requires computers being used for development to be isolated. Which of the following should be implemented to provide the MOST secure environment?

discussion.content: This is correct. Key Word: Air Gapped = Isolation
this is hard for not native speakers :D

comments.content: You probably took the test already but a bastion host is name for the poor public facing servers left in a DMZ or just outside the network. They host services and are harden to withstand attacks since there are outside the network.
Thank you!

discussion.content: Can some please explain the bastion host?

Answer: B
Answer: B
An airgap is a metaphor for physical isolation, indicating that there is a
gap of air between an isolated system and other systems. When considered
literally, an air-gapped system is not connected to any other systems. As an
example, many organizations use both classified (red) and unclassified
(black) networks. Strict rules ensure that these two systems are not connected
to each other. Some rules require that any cable from a red network must be
physically separated from black network cables.
Code is isolation

choices.D: An ad hoc network with NAT
choices.C: A honeypot residing in a DMZ

questions.question_text: When considering IoT systems, which of the following represents the GREATEST ongoing risk after a vulnerability has been discovered?

discussion.content:
This question was on the test. Jan 24, 2020. 
As GMO has mentioned, updates and patches for these systems are not regularly provided, so I also agree with option A and picked option A at the test as well.

ANS is A
Difficulty in patching and update management
No matter how much work a manufacturer puts into creating secure hardware and software for its IoT-ready product, new vulnerabilities will inevitably be discovered at some point in the future. Updates are therefore needed to keep IoT devices secure and should be applied as soon as they are released. Yet, the nature and use of IoT devices don’t always make them easy to update regularly — if at all.

Think about sensors spread across hundreds of acres of farmland. Or IoT devices on a factory floor that cannot be taken offline for updates without hugely impacting production. Worse still, even where patches can be applied regularly, there’s often no means for the user to rollback changes to the last known good state in the event that an update leads to software corruption or instability.

comments.content:
SO, this link https://rickscloud.com/the-risks-of-iot/
seems to list complexity as 1. a main concern-- followed by 2.talk of patching and firmware updates, 
this article, and the fact that Melvin leads you to patching is enough evidence for me to pick tight intergration!

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: B
after a vulnerability has been discovered

Difficult-to-update firmware is really a risk related to IoT devices. 

CompTIA :
Some automation products often use vendor-specific software and networking protocols. As with embedded devices, security features can be poorly documented, and patch management/security response processes of vendors can be inadequate. 

But this is not the greatest risk. The GREATEST risk, in my opinion, is their integration with more critical systems.

IoT devices need to measure all kinds of things, including temperature, light levels, humidity, pressure, proximity, motion, gas/chemicals/smoke, heart/breathing rates, and so on. These are implemented as thermocouples/thermistors, infrared detectors, inductive, photoelectric, and capacitative cells, accelerometers, gyroscopes, and more.

So, when you have an IoT device that will show you the wrong temperature, once you could be informed that your building was burned
Read all the comments and most suggesting A here but everyone missed "after a vulnerability has been discovered". Just because of this I will go with B

A or B. Really hard to choose. 
I would go for 'A' since the question said it is GREATEST ongoing risk. I can just stop tight integration with other devices but updates and patches is an ongoing risk.
What does "Tight integration to existing systems" mean? That is extremely vague.

here are many instances of applications and devices (peripheraldevices especially) that remain on sale with serious known vulnerabilities in firmwareor drivers and no prospect of vendor supportfor a fix. The problem is also noticeablein consumer-grade networking appliances and in the Internet of Things (IoT). So i think its A. There will be difficulty in firmware updates.

discussion.content: Both A and B are viable. Word play here makes it a 50/50. Honestly, whoever greenlights these questions needs their heads examining.

Many embedded systems use low-cost firmware chips and the vendor
never produces updates to fix security problems or only produces
updates for a relatively short product cycle (while the device could
remain in operational use for much longer).
Many embedded systems require manual updates, which are perceived
as too time-consuming for a security department with other priorities to
perform.

Vulnerability can be used to get access to other interconnected systems, however..

"Alexa turn off the lights" if Alexa doesnt work, the whole system is broken so "tight integration": seems good to me.

I would take A as the answer but if you read this "the GREATEST ongoing risk" there is no way that the ONGOING risk is "Difficult-to-update firmware". The ONGOING risk is how much tight the IoT system is integrated, so other systems are being exposed.

This is annoying but the question says “IOT Systems” not devices. 

You can patch an IOT device but a system is a different issue and because a system of this nature is “tightly knit” where in one device failure can lead to a compromised system, the risk of losing one device is minuscule compared to having your entire system affected. 

That being said, if a device is difficult to patch then the whole logic falls apart. 

Now the question, once again mentions Systems not devices. 

So annoying haha

discussion.content: Still think it may be B, though, because systems always have need of updates, etc. IoT has one other issue, which is they are integrated with other devices/systems. Both are logical, but the overall issue still seems to be that everything is interconnected in IoT.

Agreed... it is not only difficult to update firmware, sometimes it is not even possible. That is why the provided answer is correct. Some devices will never be able to be updated but still in use in the home. 

That is why, IMHO, tight integration to existing systems is the greatest ongoing risk.

questions.question_text:
A systems administrator has been assigned to create accounts for summer interns. The interns are only authorized to be in the facility and operate computers under close supervision. They must also leave the facility at designated times each day. However, the interns can access intern file folders without supervision.
Which of the following represents the BEST way to configure the accounts? (Choose two.)

An attachment that was emailed to finance employees contained an embedded message. The security administrator investigates and finds the intent was to conceal the embedded information from public view. Which of the following BEST describes this type of message?

discussion.content: Steganography not stenography :) So it is A.

comments.content: I can't spell so thats me failing.

Nah I think this was just a typo on whoever wrote this key. I've spotted plenty of other typos/grammar errors. Plus comptia can have scummy questions, but they neverrr misspell to trick you up on an exam. I'm positive answer is B
ridiculous that they included that. are we taking a reading comprehension test or a security test?

discussion.content:
This question was on the test. Jan. 24, 2020
The provided answer is correct to the best of my knowledge.

A. Obfuscation means that we take something and make it much more difficult to understand.
B. Steganography is a technique for obscuring the presence of a message, often by embedding information within a file or other entity.
SO, steganography is the answer
The message was embedded in the email’s attachment
This is too much
the question asks for the type of message not the method. So I think the provided answer is right; the message is obfuscated.
stenography

Steganography is the technique of hiding secret data within an ordinary, non-secret, file or message in order to avoid detection.

That has to be it.

Comptia are tricky, but NOT AS MUCH AS THIS!!! This is a TYPO and in the exam you will see STAGANOGRAPHY as the answer. This is also the right answer.

Steganography - hiding a message in a file. Supports this scenario and is the correct answer.

Obfuscation - Changing the content of the message. If you can see this in the question you should take a reading class before sitting this exam.

Answer is correct. Its a trick question guys.
"STENOGRAPHY" is not the correct word.
Stenography: the action or process of writing in shorthand or taking dictation.
Steganography: the practice of concealing messages or information within other nonsecret text or data.

They are not talking about an image, but rather an embedded message. 
"The process of obfuscation is when you take one topic, and you make it much more complex to understand. ... One type of obfuscation that works with images is called steganography, where you are hiding information within a picture."

discussion.content: stenography = shorthand, it is different from steganography
This question was on my exam (5 Aug 2020). I chose A.

The following question is from Gibson's "Get Certified get ahead":

Louie hid several plaintext documents WITHIN an image file. He then
sent the image file to Tony. Which of the following BEST describes the
purpose of his actions?
A. To support steganography
B. To support integrity
C. To support availability
D. To support obfuscation

The right answer is D and the explanation is the following:
"Hiding data within data is one way to support a use case of supporting obfuscation. In this scenario, Louie is USING steganography to hide the files within the image, but that is the METHOD, not the purpose."

Now, I know that the terminology in the book question (and answers) is much more precise and straightforward, while in the CompTIA question is more vague, unclear and poorly worded (as usual). Anyway I can see enough similarity; and the explanation given in the book makes me lean slightly towards "Obfuscation" as the right answer. All in all, it's another "fifty-fifty" production, branded CompTIA.

Obfuscation adds random data to make it harder to understand the exact content, but the entire content is visible.
In this case the purpose was to conceal the content from private view. You would first think of encryption - which is not the case, so the answer is Steganography from my point of view.

Would go with Stegano on this. An attachmet, embedded message. Could be a image. 

 Obfuscation is randomising data so that it cannot be understood even when you can see it.

Steganography is hiding/concealing something in a media file like audio, image etc.

There is not a typo... if there would have one, obfuscation wouldnt be a possible answer because obfuscation and Steganography are related. This is a compTIA question... IDK if they think that you would go to a company and one of the boss will try to tricky you sending you an email asking you if you know about Stenography just to see if you really know how Steganography is spelled
The keyword is embedded. Information has been placed inside, not altered. This is an example of steganography.

comments.content: ...which I think B is supposed to be (typo).
I would also agree this question is talking about Obfuscation of the "embedded message" and "conceal the embedded information". It even said it twice.

discussion.content:
A. Keyword : conceal
Obfuscation refers to the process of concealing something important, valuable, or critical. Cybercriminals use obfuscation to conceal information such as files to be downloaded, sites to be visited, etc.

The answer must be A as stenography is the action or process of writing in shorthand and transcribing the shorthand on a typewriter.

Moreover, the question asks about the type of message rather than the attachment. Using an attachment to conceal a hidden message is steganography, whereas obscuring the content of a message itself is obfuscation.
This is a really badly crafted question

"Which of the following describes this TYPE of message" sounds like the type of message was steganography to me.. Or do you think the intent of this question was to say that the type of message was obfuscation as a result of steganography?? I swear the challenge of this test isn't the content, but the wording of the questions...
key word intent so A is correct
This should be stenography. Obfuscation is the result but stenography is the act that caused the obfuscation

3DES = Symmetric Algorithm

I was wondering why or how there could be so many incorrect answers here. I knew that This one was 3DES as SHA is for hashing and not encrypting. Thanks Illuded05jolted for solving the mystery.

AES encryption uses a single key as a part of the encryption process. The key can be 128 bits (16 bytes), 192 bits (24 bytes), or 256 bits (32 bytes) in length. Given that the fastest computer would take billions of years to run through every permutation of a 256-bit key, AES is considered an extremely secure encryption standard
